references.B98CON02SEGP: Conant, R. and J.T. Collins. 1998. A field guide to the reptiles and amphibians: eastern and central North America. Houghton Mifflin, Boston. 616 p.
references.B81VOG01NAUS: Vogt, R. G. 1981. Natural history of amphibians and reptiles of Wisconsin. Milwaukee Public Museum. 205 pp.
references.R89BRE01USGP: Bredin, E. 1989. Status report on the Northern Prairie Skink EUMECES SEPTEMTRIONALIS in Canada. Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada (COSEWIC), Ottawa. 39 pp.
references.A87SOM01USGP: Somma, L. A. 1987. Reproduction of the prairie skink, Eumeces septentrionalis, in Nebraska. Great Basin Nat. 47: 373-374.
references.A00GRI01USGP: Griffith, H., A. Ngo, and R. W. Murphy. 2000. A cladistic evaluation of the cosmopolitan genus Eumeces Wiegmann (Reptilia, Squamata, Scincidae). Russian Journal of Herpetology 7:1-16.
references.A01PIT01USGP: Pitt, W. C. 2001. Density of prairie skinks (Eumeces septentrionalis) in old-field habitats. American Midland Naturalist 146:86-93.
references.A91COL01NAUS: Collins, J. T. 1991. Viewpoint:a new taxonomic arrangement for some North American amphibians and reptiles. SSAR Herpetol. Review 22:42-43.
references.W12NAT01USGP: NatureServe. 2012. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer.
references.B82COL01NAUS: Collins, J. T. 1982. Amphibians and reptiles in Kansas. Second edition. Univ. Kansas Mus. Nat. Hist., Pub. Ed. Ser. 8. xiii + 356 pp.
references.A05SMI02USGP: Smith, H. M. 2005. Plestiodon: a replacement name for most members of the genus Eumeces in North America. Journal of Kansas Herpetology 14:15-16.
references.A89SOM02USGP: Somma, L. A., and P. A. Cochran. 1989. Bibliography and subject index of the prairie skink, Eumeces septentrionalis (Baird) (Sauria: Scincidae). Great Basin Nat. 49:525-534.
references.B79BEH01NAUS: Behler, J. L., and F. W. King. 1979. The Audubon Society field guide to North American reptiles and  amphibians. Alfred A. Knopf, New York. 719 pp.
references.A03FRE01USGP: Frese, P. W. 2003. Eumeces septentrionalis septentrionalis (northern prairie skink). Nesting behavior. Herpetological Review 34:143.
references.B87GAR01NAUS: Garrett, J. M., and D. G. Barker. 1987. A Field Guide to Reptiles and Amphibians of Texas. Texas Monthly Press, Austin, Texas. 225 pp.
references.B00DIX02USGP: Dixon, J. R. 2000. Amphibians and reptiles of Texas. Second edition. Texas A & M University Press, College Station.

habitat_description:
The range for the prairie skink includes southern Manitoba, Minnesota, and northwestern Wisconsin south through the eastern Dakotas, Iowa, eastern Nebraska, Kansas and adjacent northwestern Missouri (Figg 1993), Oklahoma, and western Arkansas to coastal Texas and northwestern Louisiana (Conant and Collins 1991).

In general, habitat for this species includes open sandy areas of pine barrens and bracken grassland, grassy dunes, sandy banks of creeks and rivers and along roadsides, open grass-covered rocky hillsides near streams, and forest edges and woodland; this semifossorial lizard is often under ground cover, fallen logs, or debris. Eggs are laid under logs, boards, rocks, or other objects in shallow nests dug in loose moist soil (Frese 2003).
